Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Housing, Family, and Economy in a Post-Socialist Context

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cultural Anthropology Program supports research on the local-level effects of global processes. This research project fits into that category through its focus on how social and cultural change is brought about by engagement with the global economy. The researcher asks, "What happens to local cultural and social norms when basic human needs that used to be met through social and family obligations are purchased on the open market instead?" The researcher focuses on housing but in human history similar transformations have occurred in many areas, including health care, education, and access to natural resources such as water and land. Through a case study of a situation where the change has happened recently and society is still adjusting, we can better understand the complex ramifications of other changes, past and future, as well.

The research will be conducted by Brandeis University graduate student, Mengqi Wang, under the direction of Dr. Elizabeth Ferry. Wang will undertake research in eastern China on how changes in China's housing market, induced by greater engagement with the global economy, have affected cultural notions of family, marriage, and gender. The opening up of the Chinese housing market in the late 1990s was followed by years of inflation and then, since mid-2011, deflation. This has proved a challenge for families who bought when the market was high, often to fulfill a cultural obligation for the groom's family to provide housing as a marital gift. The resulting crisis has produced contested gender and economic norms that are centered on people's definitions of the rights to housing despite the changed context of post-socialist mortgage practices. Wang will gather data in multiple sites, including real estate agencies, financial institutions, and households of marital housing buyers. Data collection methods will include interviews, participant observation, and compilation of historical cultural materials. Findings from this research will elucidate the complex micro-level processes through which cultural and social transformations takes place as local communities become more directly affected by global economic forces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past decade, following the economy reform that replaced the socialist housing allocation system with a real estate market, housing prices in most big Chinese cities have increased almost tenfold. The real estate market has also become the hottest avenue of wealth accumulation for local governments, real estate companies, and ordinary Chinese families. Private homeownership has been turned from a desire to a necessity for the Chinese people, epitomized by the wide-spread practice of buying hunfang, translated as marriage housing, for newly-wed couples. Furthermore, as more people started to view private home ownership as a necessity, various types of housing activisms have emerged and become more frequent.

 

This project examined the interplay of cultural practices and economic transactions in the making of China’s real estate market through ethnographic fieldwork among developers, realtors, and homebuyers. Through field research in Nanjing, southeast China, the investigator examines how various market players, including local governments, developers, real estate agencies, and home-buying families engage in real estate development and transactions. The project particularly focused on the widespread Chinese practice of buying “marriage housing” for newly wed couples. As the first research conducted on this practice, the results contribute to the fields of economic anthropology, kinship and gender studies, and studies of housing in China. The outcome of this project offers an intimate view of the individuals and families striving to put roots down in the cities through private homeownership in contemporary China. In so doing, the project challenges neoliberal views on property ownership and the spontaneous market by offering a detailed and holistic analysis of the making of housing as commodity in Nanjing, southeast China.

 

With the support of the National Science Foundation, the researcher conducted a yearlong ethnographic fieldwork in East Nanjing, southeast China. In fieldwork, the scholar utilized a range of research methods, including participant observation, semi-structured interviews, and focus group discussions, to document and analyze real estate practices in contemporary China. Data collected through these diverse research methods then enabled the project to situate housing transactions in the context of family reproduction and transformation in contemporary China.

 

This project offers insights into China’s fastest growing and potentially most risky economic sector, the real estate economy, by engaging contemporary social and economic issues on the right to housing with anthropological theory. Capturing the anxiety, momentum, and struggle people go through in reaching an envisioned state of “at home” in urban China, the project diagrams the shifting and contested forms of valuation of residential properties enabled by various market practices in China. Given the increasing importance of China’s role as a stakeholder in the world economy system, this project captures the economic, as well as sociocultural, transformation of housing tenure in China.
